RUTH: My life is in front of me
and I have to cope with it,
and so I can't be afraid of it.

RONALD: So often,
people of my cultural heritage,

we get such a raw deal
because we're defined
as being aggressive or loud,

when, if anything, my mannerisms
define somebody who's frustrated,

exhausted
and struggling to be heard.

SEBASTIAN: People with dementia
are people.
They're human beings.

RACHEL: Like me.
RONALD: Just like me.

GLYNIS: And me.
RUTH: And me.
RONALD: And just like you.

RACHEL: Memory loss
can be one of the symptoms

that people initially
experience,

but it isn't always a symptom
that people get.

SEBASTIAN: Dementia is an umbrella
term, a syndrome, if you like,

that describes any progressive
change in memory
and other thinking abilities.

And there are over 100 different
diseases that can cause dementia,

the most commonly known of which
is Alzheimer's disease.

RACHEL: People might notice changes
in their thinking or their ability
to process information.
Changes in sleep.

Sometimes people talk about
being in a mist.
RONALD: It's so hard to explain.

Sometimes it's as if I'm falling
and I have to catch myself.

I know something's wrong,
but I can't put it into words.
RACHEL: Many people with dementia

may at some point
move into a care home.
There's no right or wrong.

ILA: There's a lot of stigma
attached

with having a relative
going into a home.

Ultimately, although
it was very difficult

and we took a long time over it,
it was her decision.

RUTH: Well, I suppose
in the beginning

you don't know how it all works out,
you know?

But I'm still here
and I can't imagine that
it could be better anywhere else.

ILA: The move has allowed us
to have more quality time together.

RACHEL: Whether a person's
in a hospital or a care home,
or in fact in their own home,

visiting helps maintain
that connection.
GLYNIS: I love being with my family.

I might not remember everything, but
it's good to have people together.

ILA: I find when I see my mum,
it just brings us both to life.

RACHEL: Even after
you've visited somebody,

they often feel really good
for quite a while.
You might not see that.

SEBASTIAN: People
living with dementia
can also feel very isolated.
It's about sharing an experience.

RACHEL: Connections with
the wider family,

and that might be young children
or older children,
are actually really important.

Simple facial expressions
and gestures can enable huge joy.

SEBASTIAN: If you get dementia,
it is not your fault.

Dementia is not
an inevitable part of ageing.

It's caused by a specific set
of diseases
which gradually erode the brain.

Currently, only about
a third of people realise

that there are things they can do to
help reduce their risk of dementia,
such as keeping their heart healthy,

by staying mentally sharp
and active,

and also staying socially connected
to other people.
RONALD: Wow.
Well, that doesn't apply to me.

SEBASTIAN: Lots of people focus on
what people with dementia can't do.

Some people also think that
when you get dementia,

your whole brain switches off,
and it's simply not true.

RONALD: I live well by
trying to live with purpose
through creativity and the arts.

GLYNIS: I've been involved
in some campaigns and talks.

I don't want to sit in a chair
all day, or...

You know, I want to get out
and go and find out things.

GLYNIS'S HUSBAND: The key factor
for all things is,

if you are loved,
you will cope with it.

And that's why I can cope
with dementia.
RONALD: Making music, writing music

and translating a lot
of my thoughts and feelings.

RUTH: I have lived with this
for some time already,
and I accept it.

SEBASTIAN: If we empower people -
not just people with dementia,

but their friends
and their families -

then I think people
can lead better lives.

RONALD: See the person
and not the diagnosis.
